p: Sap sweetness (i.e., sugar content) is influenced by tree health and the maple species tapped. Healthy trees with large crowns and high growth rates tend to provide sweeter sap [ 8]. Sap from the sugar maple ( Acer saccharum Marsh.), whose range covers southeastern Canada and the northeastern United States ( Fig 1), is preferred for maple syrup production because its sugar concentration is superior to other species such as the red maple ( Acer rubrum L.) [ 9, 10]. Warm summer temperatures (which stimulate maple growth) and cold winter temperatures increase sap sugar concentrations in the following sap flow season [ 11].
